In "Terror Factory: Inside the FBI's Manufactured War on Terrorism," Trevor Aaronson covers a number of specific cases of FBI sting operations and informant programs aimed at investigating and preventing terrorism. Some of the cases covered in the book include:

1. The Newburgh Four: A case in which the FBI used an informant to entrap four men in a fake bomb plot against synagogues in New York.
2. The Portland Seven: A case in which the FBI used an informant to entrap seven individuals in a fake plot to travel to Afghanistan to fight against U.S. forces.
3. The Fort Dix Five: A case in which the FBI used an informant to entrap five men in a fake plot to attack a military base in New Jersey.
4. The Lackawanna Six: A case in which the FBI used an informant to entrap six men in a fake plot to support al-Qaeda.
5. The Liberty City Seven: A case in which the FBI used an informant to entrap seven men in a fake plot to blow up the Sears Tower in Chicago.

These cases serve as examples of the FBI's tactics in fighting terrorism and provide insight into the FBI's use of sting operations and informant programs in the post-9/11 era. Aaronson's book offers a critical examination of these cases and argues that the FBI has created a "terror factory" by entrapping individuals in fake terrorism plots and creating the appearance of a more significant terrorism threat than actually exists.
